specJson.name: brightics.function.clustering$mean_shift
specJson.label: Mean Shift
specJson.description:
Mean shift clustering aims to discover “blobs” in a smooth density of samples. It is a centroid-based algorithm, which works by updating candidates for centroids to be the mean of the points within a given region. These candidates are then filtered in a post-processing stage to eliminate near-duplicates to form the final set of centroids.

Deciding appropriate value of `bandwidth` is important. Inappropriate `bandwidth` can cause modes to be merged, or generate additional “shallow” modes. The best cases to use mean shift clustering are 1) when there are not too many data because it would take lots of calculating time, 2) when we cannot predict the distribution of data so that we do not know how many clusters would be created. Application domains include cluster analysis in computer vision and image processing.

params.label: Input Columns
params.description: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible.

params.label: Bandwidth
params.description: Window size used in the RBF kernel. It has a physical meaning unlike 'k' of K-Means.

params.label: Bin Seeding
params.description: If true, initial kernel locations are the location of the discretized version of points (by binding points into grid), therefore algorithm will be speeded up.

params.label: Minimum Bin Frequency
params.description: To speed up the algorithm, accept only those bins with at least minimum bin frequency points as seed.

params.label: Cluster All
params.description: If true, then all points are clustered, even those orphans that are not within any kernel. Orphans are assigned to the nearest kernel. If false, then orphans are given cluster label -1.

specJson.summary: This function is a Mean Shift Clustering model which is a nonparametric clustering algorithm.

md: # Mean Shift This function is a Mean Shift Clustering model which is a nonparametric clustering algorithm. ## Description Mean shift clustering aims to discover 'blobs' in a smooth density of samples. It is a centroid-based algorithm, which works by updating candidates for centroids to be the mean of the points within a given region. These candidates are then filtered in a post-processing stage to eliminate near-duplicates to form the final set of centroids. Deciding appropriate value of `bandwidth` is important. Inappropriate `bandwidth` can cause modes to be merged, or generate additional “shallow” modes. The best cases to use mean shift clustering are 1) when there are not too many data because it would take lots of calculating time, 2) when we cannot predict the distribution of data so that we do not know how many clusters would be created. Application domains include cluster analysis in computer vision and image processing. Reference - - ## Properties ### VA #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. #### OUTPUT 1. **out_table**: (Table) A table that contains input `table`'s column and prediction column as `Prediction Column Name`. 2. **model**: (Model) Trained Mean Shift Clustering model. #### PARAMETER 1. **Input Columns***: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible. 2. **Prediction Column Name**: Column name for prediction. 3. **Bandwidth**: Window size used in the RBF kernel. It has a physical meaning unlike 'k' of K-Means. 4. **Bin Seeding**: If true, initial kernel locations are the location of the discretized version of points (by binding points into grid), therefore algorithm will be speeded up. * Default value: False 5. **Minimum Bin Frequency**: To speed up the algorithm, accept only those bins with at least minimum bin frequency points as seed. 6. **Cluster All**: If true, then all points are clustered, even those orphans that are not within any kernel. Orphans are assigned to the nearest kernel. If false, then orphans are given cluster label -1. * Default value: True 7. **Group By**: Columns to group by. ### Python #### USAGE ``` mean_shift(table, input_cols, prediction_col='prediction', bandwidth=None, bin_seeding=False, min_bin_freq=1, cluster_all=True, group_by=None) ``` #### INPUT 1. **table***: (Table) Training data in a Table. #### OUTPUT 2. **model**: (Model) Trained Mean Shift Clustering model. #### PARAMETER 1. **input_cols***: Columns to select as input. Only values in numeric type are possible. * Type: *list[str]* 2. **prediction_col**: Column name for prediction. * Type: *str* * Default value: prediction 3. **bandwidth**: Window size used in the RBF kernel. It has a physical meaning unlike 'k' of K-Means. * Type: *float* * Default / Range: None (value > 0) 4. **bin_seeding**: If true, initial kernel locations are the location of the discretized version of points (by binding points into grid), therefore algorithm will be speeded up. * Type: *bool* * Default value: False 5. **min_bin_freq**: To speed up the algorithm, accept only those bins with at least minimum bin frequency points as seed. * Type: *int* * Default / Range: 1 (value >= 1) 6. **cluster_all**: If true, then all points are clustered, even those orphans that are not within any kernel. Orphans are assigned to the nearest kernel. If false, then orphans are given cluster label -1. * Type: *bool* * Default value: True 7. **group_by**: Columns to group by. * Type: *list[str]* * Default value: None ## Example ### VA **[Sample Model]** In this tutorial workflow, sample_iris data is used to Mean Shift Clustering. The generated model is afterward applied to a test dataset to predict the cluster by using Mean Shift Predict function. The parameter settings used in the function are shown below. ++Parameters++ 1. **Input Columns***: sepal_length, sepal_width 2. **Prediction Column Name**: prediction 3. **Bandwidth**: 1 4. **Bin Seeding**: False 5. **Minimum Bin Frequency**: 1 6. **Cluster All**: True 7. **Group By**: None ### Python ``` from brightics.function.clustering import mean_shift input_table = inputs[0] result = mean_shift(table=input_table, input_cols=['sepal_length', 'sepal_width'], prediction_col='prediction', bandwidth=None, bin_seeding=False, min_bin_freq=1, cluster_all=True, group_by=None) output = result['model'] ``` In this python script, sample_iris data is used to train an Mean Shift Clustering. The generated model is afterward applied to a test dataset to predict the cluster by using Mean Shift Predict function.
